occurrences.line_text: From liuing eyes her open shame to hide,
And downe he fell, with dread of shame sore terrifide.
With rosie cheekes, for shame as blushing red;
Either for grieuous shame, or for great teene,
All wrongs haue mends, but no amends of shame.
To hide her shame and loathly filthinesse;
And end their daies with irrenowmed shame.
And with reprochfull shame mine honour shent,
Certes (said he) well mote I shame to tell
And now is fled; foule shame him follow, where he went.
For all so great shame after death I weene,
And saw no meanes to scape, of shame affrayd,
Such prayse is shame; but honour vertues meed
So shakes off shame, ne thinks how erst she did her hide.
That vnto knighthood workes much shame and woe;
Then wound of gealous worme, and shame of such repriefe.
That knights & knighthood doest with shame vpbray,
Losse is no shame, nor to be lesse then foe,
To worke such shame. Therefore I thee exhort,
And Atin aie him pricks with spurs of shame & wrong.
Tho vp he started, stird with shame extreme,
The shame and death, which will thee soone inuade?
And Shame his vgly face did hide from liuing eye.
That were it not for shame, he would retire,
And with foule cowardize his carkasse shame,
Which them appeached, prickt with guilty shame,
This fround, that faund, the third for shame did blush,
She answerd nought, but more abasht for shame,
All naked without shame, or care of cold,
For with all shame that sacred throne he fild:
Without or robe, or rag, to hide his shame.
The whiles the Prince prickt with reprochfull shame,
But shame and sad reproch, here to be red,
Or shame, that euer should so fowle defects
Fled all away for feare of fowler shame.
And stared ghastly, some for inward shame,
Great shame and sorrow of that fall he tooke;
For to reuenge that foule reprochfull shame,
For knight to leaue his Ladie were great shame,
That all regard of shame she had discust,
Such loue is hate, and such desire is shame.
For thy great wonder were it, if such shame
In shame of knighthood, as I largely can report.
To reskew her from shame, and to reuenge her wrong.
To bene auenged of the shame, he did
They three be dead with shame, the Squire liues with renowne.
Faire death it is to shonne more shame, to dy:
Whereof conceiuing shame and foule disgrace,
But greatest shame was to that maiden twin,
Or else for feare of shame and fowle disgrace.
And grudg'd to see the counterfet should shame
For shame, but more for feare of his grim sight,
Or else for shame, so fowle reproch to shonne,
But shame of all, that doe for honor striue,
And mickle perill to be put to shame.
Behinde him was Reproch, Repentance, Shame;
Reproch the first, Shame next, Repent behind:
Shame most ill fauourd, bestiall, and blind:
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
Shame burning brond-yrons in her hand did hold:
Yet dread of shame, and doubt of fowle dishonor
And shame, he shewd him selfe to be dismayd,
And falsly seekst a vertuous wight to shame?
Let vgly shame and endlesse infamy
To let them passe at will, for dread of shame.
(For so to lose a Lady, were great shame)
With loue of her, and shame of such mesprize.
And cast t'auenge the shame doen to his freend:
And touched was with secret wrath and shame
To shame vs all with this, Vngirt vnblest.
Shame and dishonour hath vnto me donne;
Shame be his meede (quoth he) that meaneth shame.
Shame be his meede (quoth he) that meaneth shame.
In shame of knighthood and fidelitie;
The shame of men, and plague of womankind,
If wrathfull wight, then fowle rebuke and shame
But now in feare of shame she more did stond,
Wherein the honor both of Armes ye shame,
But sooth it was not sure for womanish shame,
Saying it was to Knight vnseemely shame,
Great Brontes, and Astraeus, that did shame
And shame on you, ï¿½ men, which boast your strong
And with vile curses, and reprochfull shame
The which another did, who now is fled with shame.
He chose with shame to beare that Ladies head
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
He fear'd least they with shame would him pursew.
He much was mou'd at so vnworthie shame,
And turn'd aside for shame to heare, what he did tell.
It's punishment enough, that all his shame doe see.
So ought all faytours, that true knighthood shame,
Yet though him selfe did shame on womankinde
Partly with shame, and partly with dismay,
Me iustly terme, that to this shame am brought,
Then sith ye needs (quoth he) will know my shame,
Which some hath put to shame, and many done be dead.
And venge the shame, that she to Knights doth show.
T'auenge that shame, they did on him commit;
In womans weedes, that is to manhood shame,
Be hang'd on high, that mote his shame bewray;
But dread of shame my doubtfull lips doth still restraine.
Great shame to lose so long employed paines,
And greater shame t'abide so great misprize,
Thy maisters shame, in harlots bondage tide.
And many brought to shame by treason treacherous.
At sight thereof abasht with secrete shame,
But lastly to make proofe of vtmost shame,
And lastly, that no shame might wanting be,
Flying from place to place with cowheard shame,
But for vyld treasons, and outrageous shame,
To whom he wont shew all the shame he might,
Exiled her, that all the world spake shame.
To whom for endlesse horrour of his shame,
And counted but a recreant Knight, with endles shame.
That is the greatest shame and foulest scorne,
To whom Sir Burbon, blushing halfe for shame,
And stouped oft his head from shame to shield;
No shame to stoupe, ones head more high to reare,
Vnto this shame, and my young hope subuert,
He was ymett, who with vncomely shame
And if none do, yet shame shal thee with shame requight.
And if none do, yet shame shal thee with shame requight.
Yet answerd thus; Not vnto me the shame,
No greater shame to man then inhumanitie.
Then doe your selfe, for dread of shame, forgoe
For shame he weend a sleeping wight to wound.
Yet not content, more to increase his shame,
Against both which that knight wrought knightlesse shame.
And tooke with him the head, the signe of shame.
But as thou hast thy steed forlorne with shame,
With wrathfull fury for so foule a shame,
Withouten thought of shame or villeny,
To worke his vtter shame, and throughly him confound.
He Turpine doth defeate, and shame
But he them spotted with reproch, or secrete shame.
But by what meanes that shame to her befell,
That durst so boldly, without let or shame,
The meede whereof shall shortly be thy shame,
Yet further hast thou heaped shame to shame,
Yet further hast thou heaped shame to shame,
Is greatest shame: for oft it falles, that strong
Hence to professe: for shame is to adorne
For all that shame, which kindled inward hate.
Great shame in lieges blood to be embrew'd.
Shame would be hid. But whenas Enias
The greatest shame that euer eye yet saw?
So inward shame of her vncomely case
As I it past, that were too great a shame,
Thought sure t'auenge his grudge, & worke his foe great shame.
But gentle Shepheard pardon thou my shame,
Who when the shamed shield of slaine Sans foy
Faire knighthood fowly shamed, and doest vaunt
For suffering such abuse, as knighhood shamed,
Ne all are shamed by the fault of one;
But what is he, by whom ye shamed were?
Had him abusde, and shamed yesterday;
And eke all knights hast shamed with this knightlesse part.
Let fall her eyen, as shamefast to the earth,
Then to the knight with shamefast modestie
You shamefast are, but Shamefastnesse it selfe is shee.
Tho shaking off all doubt and shamefast feare,
When they haue shaken off the shamefast band,
You shamefast are, but Shamefastnesse it selfe is shee.
And next to her sate goodly Shamefastnesse,
Whereto her bashfull shamefastnesse ywrought
Haue knit themselues in Venus shamefull chaine;
And shamefull treason, who through guile hath slayn
Entrapped slew, and brought to shamefull graue.
Till scornd of God and man a shamefull death he dide.
And came to shamefull end. And them beside
And Phoebus flying so most shamefull sight,
And them coniure t'auenge this shamefull iniury.
And read, who hath ye wrought this shamefull plight.
That wrought the shamefull fact, which I did shew;
Ne blame your honour with so shamefull vaunt
And Hengist eke soone brought to shamefull death.
To reskew her from shamefull villany.
Tho whenas all were put to shamefull flight,
Such shamefull lusts who loaths not, which depart
For they, how euer shamefull and vnkind,
Shamefull deceipt, and daunger imminent;
His shamefull head from his auengement strong.
Their brother to reproch and shamefull flight:
And in all shamefull sort him selfe with her defile.
How suffrest thou such shamefull cruelty,
Perdy not so; (said she) for shamefull thing
That hast with shamefull spot of sinfull lust
He with his shamefull lust doth first deflowre,
For horrour of his shamefull villany.
That shamefull Hag, the slaunder of her sexe,
Then lead that shamefull life, vnworthy of a Knight.
Most shamefull, most vnrighteous, most vntrew,
And thee captyued in this shamefull place?
A shamefull vse as euer I did heare,
But to the shamefull doer it afford.
And shamefull Knight, of whom she did complaine.
With bitter termes of shamefull infamy;
Much greater griefe and shamefuller regret
Shamefully at her rayling all the way,
With Elfin sword, most shamefully betrade?
How shamefully that Maid he did torment.
Would him disarme, and treaten shamefully,
And shamefully reproued for his rudenesse fond.
So shamefully forlorne of womankind;
Where she had them both shamefully fordonne,
Where he full shamefully was hanged by the hed.
Them fouly rent, and shamefully defaced had.
He for such basenesse shamefully him shent,
On him, that had so shamefully him shent:
And halfe enraged at her shamelesse guise,
So shamelesse beauty soone becomes a loathy sight.
With all those shames, that erst ye spake me to deface.
That, were it not for shame,---So turned from him wroth.
To sit and rest the walkers wearie shankes,
Shap'd like a heart, yet bleeding of the wound,
But th'other halfe did womans shape retaine,
Then womans shape man would beleeue to bee.
In shape and life more like a monster, then a man.
To seeme like Truth, whose shape she well can faine,
And that misformed shape mis-shaped more:
More vgly shape yet neuer liuing creature saw.
What shape, what shield, what armes, what steed, what sted,
Whose shape or person yet I neuer saw,
Her louers shape, and cheualrous aray;
And brutish shape thrust downe to hell below,
That vgly shape so sore her terrifide,
Another Florimell, in shape and looke
For euery shape on him he could endew:
And as he better did their shape auize,
Twise was he seene in soaring Eagles shape,
In Satyres shape Antiopa he snatcht:
That by her monstrous shape might easily be red.
But some celestiall shape, that flesh did beare:
Yet was no man, but onely like in shape,
And oft admir'd his monstrous shape, and oft
He wilfully did cut and shape anew;
But it in shape and beautie did excell
That of his shape appear'd no litle moniment.
To leaue his proper forme, and other shape to take.
Whose dreadfull shape was neuer seene of none
Whose vgly shape none euer saw, nor kend,
So hideous is her shape, so huge her hed,
For thy it round and hollow shaped was,
Him shaped thus, she deckt in garments gay,
They wore rich Mitres shaped like the Moone,
Of sundry shapes, yet all ill fauored:
Such vgly monstrous shapes elswhere may no man reed.
As many formes and shapes in seeming wise,
The antique shapes of kings and kesars straunge & rare.
And vgly shapes did nigh the man dismay,
Infinite shapes of things dispersed thin;
Whose hideous shapes were like to feends of hell,
Most vgly shapes, and horrible aspects,
But are into these fearefull shapes disguiz'd
Was ouer-wrought, and shapes of naked boyes,
Infinite shapes of creatures men do fynd,
Disguiz'd in thousand shapes, that none might him bewray.)
Features of beautie, and all shapes select,
Infinite shapes of creatures there are bred,
To dreadfull shapes he did himselfe transforme,
For she could d'on so manie shapes in sight,
Cast into sundry shapes by wondrous skill,
Whose shapes seem'd not like to terrestriall boyes,
In thousand dreadful shapes doth mongst them stalke,
Shapt like a Ladies head, exceeding shone,
Shapt like a maid, that such ye may her know;
All shap't according their conditions,
Shapt like a horses shoe, who list to seeke it there.
And perfectly well shapt in euery lim,
In PhÃ¦drias flit barke ouer that perlous shard.
Which shar'd to them the spoiles that he had got aliue.
Should equally be shard betwixt vs tway:
Her ventayle shard away, and thence forth glaunst
But wheresoeuer it did light, it throughly shard.
That a large share it hewd out of the rest,
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
To whom no share in armes and cheualrie
These two were twinnes, & twixt them two did share
And shields did share, & mailes did rash, and helmes did hew.
Whether of them in her should haue the greater share.
He part of his small feast to her would share;
And each of either take his share aright.
And had encroched vppon others share,
Or else two falses, of each equall share;
And throwne it vp vnto my brothers share:
But that the sea it to my share did lay?
A Goshauke, which hath seized for her share
And wish, that he part of his spoyle might share.
Whose share, her guiltlesse bloud they would present,
Amongst themselues, and did their labours share,
But wisht, that with that shepheard he mote dwelling share.
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
Aliue, then to him selfe be shared dead;
Halfe of her shield he shared quite away,
Be sold, and mongst them shared equally.
To them by equall shares in equall fee:
He with Pyrrochles sharp debatement made;
And in his clownish hand a sharp bore speare he shooke.
Ne the sharp Northerne wind thereon to showre,
Nor Aeolus sharp blast could worke them any wrong.
And the sharpe yron did for anger eat,
Haue reft away with his sharpe rending clawes:
And with sharpe shrilling shriekes doe bootlesse cry,
He to him raught a dagger sharpe and keene,
And sharpe Remorse his hart did pricke and nip,
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
So many furies and sharpe fits did haunt,
With sharpe intended sting so rude him smot,
And drew her on the ground, and his sharpe sword,
Sharpe by thy wounds, but sweet the medicines bee,
Their sharpe assault right boldly did rebut,
And in her hand a sharpe bore-speare she held,
The gnawing anguish and sharpe gelosy,
And deadly sharpe he held, whose heads were dight
That the sharpe steele arriuing forcibly
Diuinely shone, and two sharpe winged sheares,
Whereat renfierst with wrath and sharpe regret,
For their sharpe wounds, and noyous iniuries,
He had a sharpe foresight, and working wit,
Bent hollow beetle browes, sharpe staring eyes,
On whose sharpe clifts the ribs of vessels broke,
To which sharpe thornes and breres the way forstall,
And with sharpe fits thy tender hart oppresseth sore.
Till that old Glauce gan with sharpe repriefe,
But with sharpe speare the rest made dearly knowne.
Of his sharpe darts and whot artillerie;
Whose shadie boughes sharpe steele did neuer lop,
Her sharpe rebuke full litle did esteeme;
From the sharpe Hauke, which her attached neare,
And with sharpe threates her often did assaile,
And the sharpe steele doth riue her hart in tway,
Reproch sharpe stings, Repentance whips entwind,
Whose sharpe prouokement them incenst so sore,
When Britomart with sharpe auizefull eye
Right sore agrieued at her sharpe reproofe,
More sharpe then points of needles did proceede,
And sharpe rebuke, for being ouer bold;
So sharpe a battell, that so many did dismay.
Now with sharpe threats; but threats the more increast their mood.
When as their sharpe contention he had ceased,
With a sharpe showre of arrowes, which them staid,
With her sharpe Cemitare at him she flew,
That his sharpe sword he threw from him apart,
With his sharpe wheeles, in his first rages heat,
And with sharpe reasons rang her such a pele,
And their sharpe speares doe both together smite
In which her cursed tongue full sharpe and short
And oft recuile to shunne his sharpe despight.
And in his left he held a sharpe borespeare,
And forth at last did breake in speaches sharpe and fell.
Seeing his sharpe assault and cruell stoure
And threatning his sharpe clawes, now wanting powre to straine.
Least that the beasts sharpe teeth had any wound
And a curre-dog; that doe him sharpe assay
The bitter anguish of their sharpe disease,
And with sharpe words did bitterly vpbrayd;
With his sharpe sword he fiercely at him flew,
Till the sharpe passion being ouerpast,
With his sharpe steele, and ran at him amaine
His poinant speare, and sharpely gan to spurne
When she for ought him sharpely did reproue,
But sharpely him assayld, and sore bestedde,
And layd at them so sharpely and so sore,
And euermore she did him sharpely twight
And now they doe so sharpely him assay,
Sharpely they all attonce did him assaile,
Yet he them still so sharpely did pursew,
Nathelesse so sharpely still he him pursewd,
Words sharpely wound, but greatest griefe of scorning growes.
And sharpely at him to reuile and raile,
O helpe thou my weake wit, and sharpen my dull tong.
To sharpen him, and their owne cursed tongs did straine.
Did sharpen them, and in fresh poyson steepe:
Then pricking him with his sharpe-pointed dart,
Wherein he fell, or sharper edge did feele,
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
But stings and sharpest steele did far exceed
That with thy charmes the sharpest sight doest bind,
And full of wrath, that with his sharp-head speare
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
My looser rimes (I wote) doth sharply wite,
That thus he sharply sayd; Now by my head,
So sharply he the Monster did pursew,
Whose knottie snags were sharpned all afore,
The sharpnesse of his cruell rending clawes;
And also for the sharpnesse of her rankling wound.
And with the push of his sharp-pointed speare
Her shattered ribs in thousand peeces riues,
That shattered all to peeces round about the plaine.
First he his beard did shaue, and fowly shent:
But they that Ladies lockes doe shaue away,
With shaumes, & trompets, & with Clarions sweet;
Playing on shaumes and trumpets, that from hence
And twixt them shayrd his realme by equall lots:
And Debons shayre was, that is Deuonshyre:
Yet she much whiter, but the same did hide
And ouer all a blacke stole she did throw,
As one that inly mournd: so was she sad,
Seemed in heart some hidden care she had,
And by her in a line a milke white lambe she lad.
She was in life and euery vertuous lore,
Whom to auenge, she had this Knight from far co[m]peld.
Yea but (quoth she) the perill of this place
And as she lay vpon the durtie ground,
A thousand yong ones, which she dayly fed,
She lookt about, and seeing one in mayle
For light she hated as the deadly bale,
Where plaine none might her see, nor she see any plaine.
Therewith enrag'd she loudly gan to bray,
Yet kindling rage, her selfe she gathered round,
Strangle her, else she sure will strangle thee.
Therewith she spewd out of her filthy maw
She poured forth out of her hellish sinke
Whose semblance she did carrie vnder feigned hew.
And she her selfe of beautie soueraigne Queene,
Tho can she weepe, to stirre vp gentle ruth,
My Fathers kingdome,--There she stopt with teares;
Loue of your selfe, she said, and deare constraint
Not all content, yet seemd she to appease
So slyding softly forth, she turnd as to her ease.
Then gan she waile and weepe, to see that woefull stowre.
And after him she rode with so much speede
Yet she her weary limbes would neuer rest,
He so vngently left her, whom she loued best.
She wore, with crownes and owches garnished,
She intertainde her louer all the way:
But when she saw the knight his speare aduaunce,
She soone left off her mirth and wanton play,
The Lady when she saw her champion fall,
She turning backe with ruefull countenaunce,
Melting in teares, then gan she thus lament;
Then his dull eares, to heare what she did tell;
And yeelding soft, in that she nought gain-said,
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
What not by right, she cast to win by guile,
Then was she faire alone, when none was faire in place.
Then cride she out, Fye, fye, deformed wight,
Eftsoones I thought her such, as she me told,
So left her, where she now is turnd to treen mould.
Ne euer wist, but that she was the same,
Then brought she me into this desert waste,
As all vnweeting of that well she knew,
At last she vp gan lift: with trembling cheare
To thinke how she through guilefull handeling,
Yet she most faithfull Ladie all this while
Had her abandond. She of nought affrayd,
From her vnhastie beast she did alight,
From her faire head her fillet she vndight,
Still dreading death, when she had marked long,
Quoth she, his princely puissance doth abate,
To seeke her strayed Champion, if she might attaine.
Still when she slept, he kept both watch and ward,
And when she wakt, he waited diligent,
Long she thus traueiled through deserts wyde,
By which she thought her wandring knight shold pas,
Till that at length she found the troden gras,
The same she followes, till at last she has
The same she followes, till at last she has
To whom approching she to her gan call,
She could not heare, nor speake, nor vnderstand;
With suddaine feare her pitcher downe she threw,
Face of faire Ladie she before did vew,
Full fast she fled, ne euer lookt behynd,
And home she came, whereas her mother blynd
Sate in eternall night: nought could she say,
She found them both in darkesome corner pent;
And thrise nine hundred Aues she was wont to say.
Thrise euery weeke in ashes she did sit,
But now for feare her beads she did forget.
Which hardly doen, at length she gan them pray,
That in their cotage small, that night she rest her may.
In stead of rest, she does lament, and weepe
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
Then furthest from her hope, when most she weened nie.
Soone as she parted thence, the fearefull twaine,
And still amidst her rayling, she did pray,
And that in endlesse error she might euer stray.
But when she saw her prayers nought preuaile,
She backe returned with some labour lost;
And in the way as she did weepe and waile,
If that of such a Ladie she could tellen ought.
Therewith she gan her passion to renew,
Saying, that harlot she too lately knew,
Vnto an hill; from whence when she him spyde,
She weend it was, and towards him gan ryde:
Approching nigh, she wist it was the same,
She has forgot, how many a wofull stowre
For him she late endur'd; she speakes no more
For him she late endur'd; she speakes no more
Before her stands her knight, for whom she toyld so sore.
Such ioy made Vna, when her knight she found;
Who told her all that fell in iourney as she went.
Yet is she now in more perplexitie,
And piteous plaints she filleth his dull eares,
And all the way she wets with flowing teares:
For she is wearie of the toilesome way,
So proud she shyned in her Princely state,
Looking to heauen; for earth she did disdayne,
And sitting high; for lowly she did hate:
